Tenure Granted
Congratulations to Dr. Beth Chase-Schuman (tenure area of School Psychologist), James Stucchio (tenure area of Assistant Superintendent for Business), Erin Goldthwaite (tenure area of Districtwide Chairperson of Special Education), and Dr. Suzanne Main-Wegielnik (tenure area of School Psychologist), who were granted tenure at the recommendation of the Superintendent at the May 12th Board of Education meeting. The public meeting was conducted via zoom, where upon the Superintendent, Robert C. Fenter, the Board of Education, and Administration offered their congratulations with the highest of praise and support. Each recipient has distinguished themselves as outstanding in their field, bringing their knowledge, leadership, and impressive work ethic to the District. All agreed with confidence that their insight will serve the community well in the years to come, and thanked them for their hard work and dedication.

The public can view the administrative speeches honoring each recipient at https://www.csh.k12.ny.us/Page/17

Finally, I just started a book of short stories, Exhalation, by Ted Chiang. I've only read one story so far, but it was quite good, and I look forward to the others. Keep reading!!

Federal Reserve Challenge
Each year the Federal Reserve Bank of New York holds the High School Fed Challenge. A team of students is charged with creating a presentation of compiled economic indicators to formulate an analysis of the current state of the economy and the risks for the future. The students present their findings to judges and make their recommendations of monetary policy actions. Following the presentation, there is a question and answer component to the competitions, where the judges subject them to an extensive line of questioning. This year we had a high achieving, creative team where all members contributed to the impressive presentation of economic analysis which was especially challenging due to the recent economic volatility. The team members are Anna Tesoriero, Andrew Khanin, Katherine Brennan, Julia Bavaro, Kaitlyn Fare, Matthew Adragna, Colin Bacchi, Wylie Brimeyer, Lindsay DeRosa, and Alexandra Lynch.

West Side - 6th Grade Triptych
Sixth grade students learned about the art of a triptych. This is the process of making a connection between three images either by subject matter, color or story to become a single unit. After taking photographs of three different people (head, body, legs), they put the images together to create a a humorous full figure and fun visual story. They used pastels to take the colors from the photograph, replicate the color and pull away with a blending technique into the negative space. Art teacher, Ms. McLaughlin, shared, "The journey was long but the students learned so much and created unbelievable mixed media masterpieces."

Thank you to everyone for sharing these wonderful insights!

Ga-ga is a variant of dodgeball that is played in a ga-ga "pit". The game combines dodging, striking, running, and jumping, with the objective of being the last person standing. Players hit the ball at each other with their hands, and are eliminated if the ball strikes them on or below the waist. So much fun!

Analyzing Otzi
Otzi the Iceman is a fascinating new exhibit at the CSH Laboratory DNA Learning Center. Otzi is a 5000-year-old man who teaches us about DNA, our human inheritance, understanding our genetic ancestry and what makes us human! Otzi’s DNA determines his relationship and that of Neanderthals to modern humans. Through analysis of Otzi’s stomach and intestines, many pollen types were revealed and studied to help scientists learn exactly when Otzi died. Lloyd Harbor fifth grade students studied pollen grains under the microscope with help from DNA Learning Center Educator, Ms. Capobianco. Prior to this, she led the students on a scavenger hunt which included skulls dating back 6 million years, skeletons and bones, bacterial illnesses, eye color, blood type and more! Students learned that not only pollen was found in Otzi’s digestive system, but also wild goat, red deer, plants and wheat. Thank you CSH Laboratory for these amazing collaborations with CSH School District.
